In the UK we call Baking Soda "Bicarb" or "Bicarbonate of Soda" because it's not only used for baking.  Calling it Baking soda at the same time as using "Baking" to describe Baking Powder is the reason for the confusion of the two products. Baking powder contains Bicarbonate of Soda and Cream of Tartar plus filler.  Bicarb is just Bicarbonate of Soda.

The yeasts aren't from the air, they're from the flour. Some hypothesize the Lactobacillus bacteria are from the bakers' hands, but it's not known for certain last I checked.

In a stove-top preparation, I took the baking soda and poured into an old pan... just laid out about an inch deep layer of the stuff, and sat it on a burner over medium (ish) heat... After a couple of minutes to allow the pan sufficient heating time, I began to slowly stir through the stuff. Within another couple of minutes, I was forced to open a window as the beginning "puffs" from the reaction began bursting into the air... They were never particularly large or obnoxious, but the steady strings of them as I stirred and rolled the powder around were aerating the stuff and making a HORRIBLY obnoxious odor as well as bringing a burning sensation to my nose and throat...

Okay... this goes on for some 15 or 20 minutes, and then steadily diminishes to relative peace again... no amount of stirring can keep it going on. Upon close inspection at this point, including a comparison with a small quantity of original baking soda, reveals that the powder cooked in the pan is somewhat darker grayish in color than the pearly white of the soda...

THIS is sodium carbonate, or "washing soda" as they called it in the older times... It must be kept in a sealed container or it draws humidity and reverts back into baking soda again, though you can cook it down to "washing soda" repeatedly without harm done... It's a cleaning booster, though I'm not entirely sure of what exact boosting qualities it carries... I do know that added in reasonable amounts to degreasing agents and other surfactant heavy soaps, the cleaning intensity is noticeably "stronger" without a lot of time or money invested toward the "novel" ingredient... There IS a point of diminishing returns, but this stuff is capable of boosting even ordinary hair-care products (like plain shampoo) into a laundry degreasing agent almost as effective as GoJo... AND my personal experimentation started with VO5 "Extra Body" shampoo, as it seems to lack all the lotions, moisturizing contaminants and other dubious "enriching" substances that might dubiously alter the formula, even if it does claim to be enriched with vitamins or essence of some kind...

In any case, you can meter the stuff directly into a load of laundry, in addition to whatever particular brand of soap you prefer, and no fear of destroying the perfume qualities... It CAN diminish some of the lifespan of some fabrics, but those are mostly not intended to be involved in degreasing or any activity that might lead to it in the first place... Still, a sparing addition of wash soda in lieu of declaring a precious garment "ruined" at once might be the better alternative all together...

SO risk assessment is UP TO YOU... ;o)

Wild yeasts (and lactic acid bacteria) do not get from the air into the dough to ferment it. Although it is true that some of it is in the air, this is not how it ends up in the dough. It is already there.

The bacteria and yeasts land upon the grains, where they have an all you can eat source of food to do their Yeastie-stuff. Those grains we mill, and use for our sourdough starters.

To be more specific on substituting baking powder, you just need to mix 2 parts cream or tartar with 1 part baking soda. So if the recipe calls for 1 tbsp (ie 3 tsp) of baking powder, you use 1 tsp baking soda and 2 tsp cream of tartar.

Or just put in 1 tsp of baking soda and some other acidic stuff, like lemon juice. It's not as intimidating as it seems. Adding too much acid or too much baking soda won't do anything negative other than change the flavour a little.
